what: Probabilistic Sensitivity Analysis for Exposure Misclassification
title: Probabilistic Sensitivity Analysis
text: use study effect smoking pregnancy breast cancer risk Fink & Lash, assume nondifferential misclassification exposure, smoking, probability density functions sensitivities (Se) specificities (Sp) among cases noncases equal uniform distributions minimum 0.7 maximum 0.95 sensitivities (0.9 0.99 respectively specificities). choose correct exposure misclassification argument type = exposure. ask 50000 replications (default 1000). Don’t shy number iterations, episensr fast. Se Sp cases (seca, spca) given list first element referring type distribution (choice constant, uniform, triangular, trapezoidal, logit-logistic, logit-normal) second element giving distribution parameters (min max uniform distribution). avoiding provide information noncases (seexp, spexp), referring nondifferential misclassification. output gives 2X2 table, observed measures association, corrected measures association. saved probsens analysis new object smoke.nd. can see elements function str(): smoke.nd list 8 elements different information analysis done saved. smoke.nd$obs.data observed 2X2 table, smoke.nd$obs.measures (observed measures association), smoke.nd$adj.measures (adjusted measures association), smoke.nd$sim.df, data frame simulated variables replication, like Se Sp, 4 cells adjusted 2X2 table, adjusted measures. episensr offers plot functions allow plotting directly saved information, example Se prior distribution: Sensibility prior distribution. combinations Se, Sp, disease (exposure) prevalence can produce negative cells corrected 2--2 table. outcome misclassification, happen frequency observed exposed cases less total number diseased individuals multiplied false-positive proportion. Negative cell counts occur false-positive proportion greater proportion cases exposed. providing values Se Sp less like random classification (.e. Se ~50% Sp ~50%), can obtain negative cell values. Note message provided chosen distribution(s) lead negative cell values, number iterations affected. default, iterations deleted simulation. However, user can keep iterations set zero setting discard FALSE. recommended shift distributions upwards 10% iterations deleted (Fox et al., 2005).

what: Probabilistic Sensitivity Analysis for Uncontrolled Confounding
title: Probabilistic Sensitivity Analysis
text: Let’s illustrate function example association occupational resins exposure lung cancer mortality studied, together presence unmeasured potential confounder, smoking (Greenland et al., 1994). adjustment age year death, Greenland et al. found 1.77 (95% CI 1.18 2.64). smoking, data , effect association? large association resins smoking remove association resins lung cancer association adjustment smoking? , know 3 bias parameters: association smoking lung cancer, prevalence smoking among unexposed resins, prevalence smoking exposed resins. Prior probability distributions given bias parameters. Prevalences smoking exposed resins, smoking unexposed resins receive prior distributions uniform 0.40 0.70. Prior distribution odds ratio associating smoking lung cancer mortality log-normal 95% limits 5 15. mean distribution [ln(15) + ln(5)] / 2 = 2.159, standard deviation [ln(15) - ln(5)] / 3.92 = 0.28. looks like : Log-normal distribution meanlog = 2.159 sdlog = 0.28. Now, let’s run probsens.conf 50,000 iterations: median adjusted 1.84 [1.21,2.82]. ratio two 95% CI bounds 2.82/1.21 = 2.33. ratio conventional 95% confidence limits 2.57/1.20 = 2.14. 2 ratios pretty close, therefore uncertainty confounding similar uncertainty random error. can plot bias-adjusted including systematic random error: Distribution 50,000 confounder-adjusted odds ratios.
code: set.seed(123) x <- rlnorm(10000, meanlog = 2.159, sdlog = 0.28) quantile(x, c(0.025, 0.975)) ##      2.5%     97.5%  ##  4.979672 14.959055 plot(density(x)) set.seed(123) greenland <- probsens.conf(matrix(c(45, 94, 257, 945),                                   dimnames = list(c("Cases+", "Cases-"), c("Res+", "Res-")),                                   nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE),                            reps = 50000,                            prev.exp = list("uniform", c(.4, .7)),                            prev.nexp = list("uniform", c(.4, .7)),                            risk = list("log-normal", c(2.159, .28))) greenland ## --Observed data--  ##          Outcome: Cases+  ##        Comparing: Res+ vs. Res-  ##  ##        Res+ Res- ## Cases+   45   94 ## Cases-  257  945 ##  ##                                      2.5%    97.5% ## Observed Relative Risk: 1.646999 1.182429 2.294094 ##    Observed Odds Ratio: 1.760286 1.202457 2.576898 ## --- ##                                            Median 2.5th percentile ##            RR (SMR) -- systematic error: 1.648388         1.166250 ## RR (SMR) -- systematic and random error: 1.645768         1.018201 ##            OR (SMR) -- systematic error: 1.841387         1.209338 ## OR (SMR) -- systematic and random error: 1.841158         1.041488 ##                                          97.5th percentile ##            RR (SMR) -- systematic error:          2.325654 ## RR (SMR) -- systematic and random error:          2.670214 ##            OR (SMR) -- systematic error:          2.822182 ## OR (SMR) -- systematic and random error:          3.278307 plot(greenland, "or_tot")

title: Additional Sensitivity Analyses
text: episensr also offers option check effect residual confounding based array approach (Schneeweiss, 2006). Even controlling confounding (design analysis study), residual confounding can still present, : confounding factors taken account (looked , adjusted , data collected ), loosely took account confounding (still presence differences groups control matching example, lost precision confounding variable e.g. categorizing continuous variable), subjects correctly classified confounding variables.

what: Simple Sensitivity Analyses in the Absence of External Information: Array Approach
title: Additional Sensitivity Analyses
text: array approach Schneeweiss provides corrected RR based apparent, confounded, RR, prevalence confounding factor among exposed unexposed, association confounder outcome. Schneeweiss provides (made-) example association TNF\(_\alpha\) blocking agents Non-Hodgkin (NH) Lymphoma rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients. Assuming observed relative risk 2, 50% RA patients progressive immunologic disease, progressive disease likely lead NH lymphoma: function takes values observed risk (2.0); covariates binary, continuous, risk difference scale; association confounder outcome (let’s say 2.5); prevalence confounder among exposed (let’s say 0.1); prevalence confounder among unexposed. adjusted RR 3.04. However, interesting keep factors constant analysis (crude risk 2.0, prevalence among unexposed, 0.5), vary imbalance hypothetical unobserved confounder (association confounder-outcome 1 5.5; prevalence among exposed, 0 1): adding fun 3-d plots!
code:
library(episensr) ## Loading required package: ggplot2 confounders.array(crude.risk = 2,                   type = "binary",                   bias_parms = c(2.5, 0.1, 0.5)) ## --Input bias parameters-- ##                               ## RR(Confounder-Disease):   2.5 ## p(Confounder+|Exposure+): 0.1 ## p(Confounder+|Exposure-): 0.5 ## --- ##  ##                         ## Adjusted RR    3.043478 ## Percent bias -34.285714 dat <- expand.grid(RR_CD = seq(1, 5.5, 0.5), P_C1 = seq(0, 1, 0.1)) dat$RR_adj <- apply(dat, 1,                     function(x) confounders.array(2,                                                   type = "binary",                                                   bias_parms = c(x[1],                                                                  x[2],                                                                  0.5))[[3]][1]) library(lattice) library(grid) wireframe(RR_adj ~ RR_CD * P_C1,           data = dat,           xlab = "RR
confounder-outcome",           ylab = "Prevalence confounder
among exposed",           zlab = "Adjusted
RR",           drape = TRUE, colorkey = TRUE,           scales = list(arrows = FALSE, cex = .5, tick.number = 10,                         z = list(arrows = FALSE), distance = c(1.5, 1.5, 1.5)),           zlim = 0:4,           light.source = c(10, 0, 10),           col.regions = rainbow(100, s = 1, v = 1,                                 start = 0, end = max(1, 100 - 1) / 100,                                 alpha = .8),           screen = list(z = -60, x = -60),           panel = function(...)           {               panel.wireframe(...)               grid.text("Observed RR = 1
Prevalence confounder
among unexposed = 0.5",                         0.125, 0.175, default.units = "native")           })

title: Quantitative Bias Analysis for Epidemiologic Data
text: use case-control study Stang et al. relation mobile phone use uveal melanoma. observed odds ratio association regular mobile phone use vs. mobile phone use uveal melanoma incidence 0.71 [95% CI 0.51-0.97]. substantial difference participation rates cases controls (94% vs 55%, respectively) selection bias impact association estimate. 2X2 table study following: use function selection shown . various episensr functions return object list containing input output variables. can check str(). 2X2 table provided matrix selection probabilities given argument bias_parms, vector 4 probabilities (guided participation rates cases controls) following order: among cases exposed, among cases unexposed, among noncases exposed, among noncases unexposed. output shows observed 2X2 table observed odds ratio (relative risk), followed corrected ones.
code: library(episensr) ## Loading required package: ggplot2 stang <- selection(matrix(c(136, 107, 297, 165),                           dimnames = list(c("UM+", "UM-"), c("Mobile+", "Mobile-")),                           nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE),                    bias_parms = c(.94, .85, .64, .25)) stang ## --Observed data--  ##          Outcome: UM+  ##        Comparing: Mobile+ vs. Mobile-  ##  ##     Mobile+ Mobile- ## UM+     136     107 ## UM-     297     165 ##  ##                                        2.5%     97.5% ## Observed Relative Risk: 0.7984287 0.6518303 0.9779975 ##    Observed Odds Ratio: 0.7061267 0.5143958 0.9693215 ## --- ##                                                  ## Selection Bias Corrected Relative Risk: 1.483780 ##    Selection Bias Corrected Odds Ratio: 1.634608

title: Quantitative Bias Analysis for Epidemiologic Data
text: Misclassification bias can assessed function misclassification. Confidence intervals corrected association due exposure misclassification also directly available, estimates can also bootstrapped (see ). confidence intervals variance corrected odds ratio estimator misclassification function computed Greenland et al. Chu et al.. Using example Chu et al. case-control study cigarette smoking invasive pneumococcal disease, unadjusted odds ratio 4.32, 95% confidence interval 2.96 6.31. Let’s say sensitivity self-reported smoking 94% specificity 97%, case control groups: corrected odds ratio now 5.02, widened 95% confidence interval (3.28 7.69). Note bias despite large sensitivity specificity. can even reproduce contour plots Chu et al. paper! Contour plot point estimates corrected odds ratio () Contour plot 95% lower confidence limit corrected Covariate misclassification available via function misclassification.cov. example, paper Berry et al. looked misclassification confounding variable vitro fertilization (IVF), confounder, resulted wrongly association increase folic acid twins. IVF increases risk twins, women undergoing IVF might likely take folic acid supplements, .e. IVF confounder vitamins twins. Data IVF available proxy used, period involuntary childlessness. However, poor proxy IVF, sensitivity 60% specificity 95%. bias parameters assumed nondifferential. ’s code episensr: non-adjusted analysis showed women taking folic acid 2.44 times likely twins, correcting misclassification IVF, risk ratio now null (= 1.0).

title: Quantitative Bias Analysis for Epidemiologic Data
text: use data cross-sectional study Tyndall et al. association male circumcision risk acquiring HIV, might confounded religion. code account unmeasured unknown confounders following, 2X2 table given matrix. choose risk ratio implementation, provide vector defining risk ratio associating confounder disease, prevalence confounder, religion, among exposed unexposed. output gives crude 2X2 table, crude relative risk confounder specific measures association exposure outcome, relationship adjusted unknown confounder, using standardized morbidity ratio (SMR) Mantel-Haenszel (MH) estimate risk ratio. Additional information also available, like 2X2 tables levels confounder. described function’s help file, bias correction used “relative risk due confounding” proposed Miettinen (Components crude risk ratio, J Epidemiol 1972, 96(2):168-172). two examples shown paper following. first one drug surveillance data analyzed cohort study, frequency drug-attributed rash relation allopurinol exposure among recipients ampicillin, sex treated potential confounding factor. can decompose numbers confounders: Outcome confounders Among males Among females get bias parameters: following results: second example, data case-control study relationship oral contraceptive use venous thrombosis age confounding factor. Outcome confounders Among 20-29 years old Among 30-39 years old bias parameters: following results:
code: tyndall <- confounders(matrix(c(105, 85, 527, 93),                               dimnames = list(c("HIV+", "HIV-"), c("Circ+", "Circ-")),                               nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE),                        type = "RR",                        bias_parms = c(.63, .8, .05)) tyndall ## --Observed data--  ##          Outcome: HIV+  ##        Comparing: Circ+ vs. Circ-  ##  ##      Circ+ Circ- ## HIV+   105    85 ## HIV-   527    93 ##  ##                                             2.5%     97.5% ##         Crude Relative Risk: 0.3479151 0.2757026 0.4390417 ## Relative Risk, Confounder +: 0.4850550                     ## Relative Risk, Confounder -: 0.4850550                     ## --- ##                                           RR_conf ## Standardized Morbidity Ratio: 0.4850550 0.7172695 ##              Mantel-Haenszel: 0.4850550 0.7172695 ## Confounder + tyndall$cfder.data ##          Circ+    Circ- ## HIV+  75.17045 2.727967 ## HIV- 430.42955 6.172033 ## Confounder - tyndall$nocfder.data ##         Circ+    Circ- ## HIV+ 29.82955 82.27203 ## HIV- 96.57045 86.82797 rash <- matrix(c(15, 94, 52, 1163),                dimnames = list(c("Rash +", "Rash -"),                                c("Allopurinol +", "Allopurinol -")),                nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) ## Outcome by confounders rash_conf <- matrix(c(36, 58, 645, 518),                     dimnames = list(c("Rash +", "Rash -"),                                     c("Males", "Females")),                     nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) ## By confounders: among males rash_males <- matrix(c(5, 36, 33, 645),                      dimnames = list(c("Rash +", "Rash -"),                                      c("Allopurinol +", "Allopurinol -")),                      nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) ## By confounders: among females rash_females <- matrix(c(10, 58, 19, 518),                        dimnames = list(c("Rash +", "Rash -"),                                        c("Allopurinol +", "Allopurinol -")),                        nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) (RR_no <- (36/(36+645))/(58/(58+518))) # RR between confounder and outcome among non-exposed ## [1] 0.5249886 (p1 <- (5+33)/(15+52)) # prevalence of confounder among exposed ## [1] 0.5671642 (p2 <- (36+645)/(94+1163)) # prevalence of confounder among unexposed ## [1] 0.5417661 rash %>% confounders(., type = "RR", bias_parms = c(RR_no, p1, p2)) ## --Observed data--  ##          Outcome: Rash +  ##        Comparing: Allopurinol + vs. Allopurinol -  ##  ##        Allopurinol + Allopurinol - ## Rash +            15            94 ## Rash -            52          1163 ##  ##                                           2.5%    97.5% ##         Crude Relative Risk: 2.993808 1.840724 4.869218 ## Relative Risk, Confounder +: 3.043245                   ## Relative Risk, Confounder -: 3.043245                   ## --- ##                                           RR_conf ## Standardized Morbidity Ratio: 3.0432448 0.9837551 ##              Mantel-Haenszel: 3.0432448 0.9837551 thromb <- matrix(c(12, 30, 53, 347),                  dimnames = list(c("Thrombosis +", "Thrombosis -"),                                  c("OC +", "OC -")),                  nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) ## Outcome by confounders thromb_conf <- matrix(c(18, 12, 158, 189),                       dimnames = list(c("Thrombosis +", "Thrombosis -"),                                       c("20-29 years old", "30-39 years old")),                       nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) ## By confounders: among 20-29 years old thromb_younger <- matrix(c(10, 18, 39, 158),                        dimnames = list(c("Thrombosis +", "Thrombosis -"),                                        c("OC +", "OC -")),                        nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) ## By confounders: among 30-39 years old thromb_older <- matrix(c(2, 12, 14, 189),                      dimnames = list(c("Thrombosis +", "Thrombosis -"),                                      c("OC +", "OC -")),                      nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) (OR_no <- (18/12)/(158/189)) # OR between confounder and outcome among non-exposed ## [1] 1.794304 (p1 <- (10+39)/(12+53)) # prevalence of confounder among exposed ## [1] 0.7538462 (p2 <- (18+158)/(30+347)) # prevalence of confounder among unexposed ## [1] 0.4668435 thromb %>% confounders(., type = "OR", bias_parms = c(OR_no, p1, p2)) ## --Observed data--  ##          Outcome: Thrombosis +  ##        Comparing: OC + vs. OC -  ##  ##              OC + OC - ## Thrombosis +   12   30 ## Thrombosis -   53  347 ##  ##                                        2.5%    97.5% ##         Crude Odds Ratio: 2.618868 1.263076 5.429973 ## Odds Ratio, Confounder +: 2.245449                   ## Odds Ratio, Confounder -: 2.245449                   ## --- ##                                         OR_conf ## Standardized Morbidity Ratio: 2.245449 1.166300 ##              Mantel-Haenszel: 2.245449 1.166300

title: Quantitative Bias Analysis for Epidemiologic Data
text: Selection misclassification bias models can bootstrapped order get confidence interval adjusted association parameter. can use ICU dataset Hosmer Lemeshow Applied Logistic Regression textbook example. replicates give negative cells adjusted 2X2 table silently ignored number effective bootstrap replicates provided output. Ten thousands bootstrap samples good number testing everything runs smoothly. , don’t afraid running , like 100,000 bootstrap samples. Bootstrap replicates can also plotted, confidence interval shown dotted lines. Bootstrap replicates confidence interval.
code: library(aplore3)  # to get ICU data data(icu)  ## First run the model misclass_eval <- misclassification(icu$sta, icu$inf,                                    type = "exposure",                                    bias_parms = c(.75, .85, .9, .95)) misclass_eval ## --Observed data--  ##          Outcome: Died  ##        Comparing: Yes vs. No  ##  ##        exposed ## case    Yes  No ##   Died   24  16 ##   Lived  60 100 ##  ##                                      2.5%    97.5% ## Observed Relative Risk: 2.071429 1.175157 3.651272 ##    Observed Odds Ratio: 2.500000 1.230418 5.079573 ## --- ##                                                                2.5%     97.5% ## Misclassification Bias Corrected Relative Risk:  3.627845                     ##    Misclassification Bias Corrected Odds Ratio:  4.871795  1.235506 19.210258 ## Then bootstrap it set.seed(123) misclass_boot <- boot.bias(misclass_eval, R = 10000) misclass_boot ## 95 % confidence interval of the bias adjusted measures:  ##    RR: 0.9595117 11.96789  ##    OR: 1.075386 19.44271  ## --- ##  Based on 9562 bootstrap replicates plot(misclass_boot, "rr")

title: Basic Sensitivity Analysis of Epidemiological Results
text: use case-control study Stang et al. relation mobile phone use uveal melanoma. observed odds ratio association regular mobile phone use vs. mobile phone use uveal melanoma incidence 0.71 [95% CI 0.51-0.97]. substantial difference participation rates cases controls (94% vs 55%, respectively) selection bias impact association estimate. 2X2 table study following: use function selection shown . 2X2 table provided matrix selection probabilities given argument bias_parms, vector 4 probabilities (guided participation rates cases controls) following order: among cases exposed, among cases unexposed, among noncases exposed, among noncases unexposed. output shows observed 2X2 table, observed odds ratio (relative risk) followed corrected ones.
code: library(episensr) #> Loading required package: ggplot2  selection(matrix(c(136, 107, 297, 165),                  dimnames = list(c("UM+", "UM-"), c("Mobile+", "Mobile-")),                  nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE),           bias_parms = c(.94, .85, .64, .25)) #> --Observed data--  #>          Outcome: UM+  #>        Comparing: Mobile+ vs. Mobile-  #>  #>     Mobile+ Mobile- #> UM+     136     107 #> UM-     297     165 #>  #>                                        2.5%     97.5% #> Observed Relative Risk: 0.7984287 0.6518303 0.9779975 #>    Observed Odds Ratio: 0.7061267 0.5143958 0.9693215 #> --- #>                                                  #> Selection Bias Corrected Relative Risk: 1.483780 #>    Selection Bias Corrected Odds Ratio: 1.634608

title: Bootstrap resampling for selection and misclassification bias models. — boot.bias
text: Generate R bootstrap replicates either selection misclassification bias functions. generates confidence interval parameter, first order normal approximation bootstrap percentile interval. Replicates giving negative cell(s) adjusted 2--2 table silently ignored.

title: Bootstrap resampling for selection and misclassification bias models. — boot.bias
code: boot.bias(bias_model, R = 1000, conf = 0.95, ci_type = c("norm", "perc"))

title: Bootstrap resampling for selection and misclassification bias models. — boot.bias
text: bias_model object class "episensr.boot", .e. either selection bias function misclassification bias function. R number bootstrap replicates. conf Confidence level. ci_type character string giving type interval required. Values can either "norm" "perc", default "norm".

title: Bootstrap resampling for selection and misclassification bias models. — boot.bias
text: list elements: model Model ran. boot_mod Bootstrap resampled object, class boot. nrep Number replicates used. bias_ciRR Bootstrap confidence interval object relative risk. bias_ciOR Bootstrap confidence interval object odds ratio. ci Confidence intervals bias adjusted association measures. conf Confidence interval.

title: Bootstrap resampling for selection and misclassification bias models. — boot.bias
code: misclass_eval <- misclassification(matrix(c(215, 1449, 668, 4296), dimnames = list(c("Breast cancer+", "Breast cancer-"), c("Smoker+", "Smoker-")), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE), type = "exposure", bias_parms = c(.78, .78, .99, .99))  set.seed(123) boot.bias(misclass_eval) #> 95 % confidence interval of the bias adjusted measures:  #>    RR: 0.8376288 1.102813  #>    OR: 0.7903447 1.137001  #> --- #>  Based on 1000 bootstrap replicates

code: # Example from Schneeweiss, S. Sensitivity analysis and external adjustment for # unmeasured confounders in epidemiologic database studies of therapeutics. # Pharmacoepidemiol Drug Safety 2006; 15: 291-303. confounders.array(crude.risk = 1.5, type = "binary", bias_parms = c(5.5, 0.5, 0.1)) #> --Input bias parameters-- #>                               #> RR(Confounder-Disease):   5.5 #> p(Confounder+|Exposure+): 0.5 #> p(Confounder+|Exposure-): 0.1 #> --- #>  #>                          #> Adjusted RR    0.6692308 #> Percent bias 124.1379310 # Examples from Patorno E., Gopalakrishnan, C., Franklin, J.M., Brodovicz, K.G., # Masso-Gonzalez, E., Bartels, D.B., Liu, J., and Schneeweiss, S. Claims-based # studies of oral glucose-lowering medications can achieve balance in critical # clinical variables only observed in electronic health records 2017; 20(4): 974- # 984. confounders.array(crude.risk = 1.5, type = "binary", bias_parms = c(3.25, 0.333, 0.384)) #> --Input bias parameters-- #>                                 #> RR(Confounder-Disease):   3.250 #> p(Confounder+|Exposure+): 0.333 #> p(Confounder+|Exposure-): 0.384 #> --- #>  #>                        #> Adjusted RR   1.598399 #> Percent bias -6.156116 confounders.array(crude.risk = 1.5, type = "continuous", bias_parms = c(1.009, 7.8, 7.9)) #> --Input bias parameters-- #>                                 #> RR(Confounder-Disease):   1.009 #> p(Confounder+|Exposure+): 7.800 #> p(Confounder+|Exposure-): 7.900 #> --- #>  #>                          #> Adjusted RR   1.50134456 #> Percent bias -0.08955729 confounders.array(crude.risk = 0.05, type = "RD", bias_parms = c(0.009, 8.5, 8)) #> --Input bias parameters-- #>                                    #> RR(Confounder-Disease):      0.009 #> mean(Confounder+|Exposure+): 8.500 #> mean(Confounder+|Exposure-): 8.000 #> --- #>  #>                      #> Adjusted RD  0.04550 #> Percent bias 9.89011

title: Compute E-value to assess bias due to unmeasured confounder. — confounders.evalue

title: Compute E-value to assess bias due to unmeasured confounder. — confounders.evalue
code: confounders.evalue(   est,   lower_ci = NULL,   upper_ci = NULL,   sd = NA,   type = c("RR", "ORc", "HRc", "diff_RR", "diff_OR"),   true_est = 1 )

title: Compute E-value to assess bias due to unmeasured confounder. — confounders.evalue
text: est Point estimate effect measure. difference continuous outcomes, standardized effect size (.e. mean outcome divided standard deviation). lower_ci Lower limit confidence interval association (relative risk, odds ratio, hazard ratio, incidence rate ratio, risk difference). upper_ci Upper limit confidence interval association (relative risk, odds ratio, hazard ratio, incidence rate ratio, risk difference). sd difference continuous outcomes, standard error outcome divided standard deviation. type Choice effect measure (relative risk, odds ratio hazard ratio rare outcomes .e. < 15 outcome -- ORc; hazard ratio common outcome .e. > 15 difference continuous outcomes, RR approximation -- diff_RR; difference continuous outcomes, approximation -- diff_OR). true_est True estimate assess E-value . Default 1 risk scale assess null value. Set different value assess non-null hypotheses.

title: Compute E-value to assess bias due to unmeasured confounder. — confounders.evalue
text: matrix observed point estimate closest confidence interval null hypothesis, expressed relative risk, corresponding E-value.

title: Compute E-value to assess bias due to unmeasured confounder. — confounders.evalue
text: VanderWeele T.J Ding P. Sensitivity analysis observational research: Introducing E-value. Annals Internal Medicine 2017;167:268-274.

title: Compute E-value to assess bias due to unmeasured confounder. — confounders.evalue
code: # The data for this example come from: # Victoria C.G., Smith P.G., Vaughan J.P., Nobre L.C., Lombardi C., Teixeira A.M. # et al. # Evidence for protection by breast-feeding against infant deaths from infectious # diseases in Brazil. # Lancet 1987;2:319-22. confounders.evalue(est = 3.9, type = "RR") #>  #> --E-value-- #>          Point estimate   CI closest to H_0 #>      RR:       3.900000                     #> E-value:       7.263034                      # The data for this example come from: # Oddy W.H, Smith G.J., Jacony P.  # A possible strategy for developing a model to account for attrition bias in a # longitudinal cohort to investigate associations between exclusive breastfeeding and # overweight and obesity at 20 years. # Annals of Nutrition and Metabolism 2014;65:234-235. confounders.evalue(est = 1.47, lower_ci = 1.12, upper_ci = 1.93, type = "ORc") #>  #> --E-value-- #>          Point estimate   CI closest to H_0 #>      RR:       1.212436            1.058301 #> E-value:       1.719944            1.306694  # The data for this example come from: # Reinisch J., Sanders S., Mortensen E., Rubin D.B. # In-utero exposure to phenobarbital and intelligence deficits in adult men. # Journal of the American Medical Association 1995;274:1518-1525 confounders.evalue(est = -0.42, sd = 0.14, type = "diff_RR") #>  #> --E-value-- #>          Point estimate   CI closest to H_0 #>      RR:      0.6823586           0.8754651 #> E-value:      2.2914593           1.5453444

title: Probabilistic sensitivity analysis for unmeasured confounding. — probsens.conf
text: case Outcome variable. variable, variable tabulated . exposed Exposure variable. reps Number replications run. prev.exp List defining prevalence exposure among exposed. first argument provides probability distribution function (constant, uniform, triangular, trapezoidal, logit-logistic, logit-normal, beta) second parameters vector. Logit-logistic logit-normal distributions can shifted providing lower upper bounds. Avoid providing values non-shifted distribution desired. constant: constant value, uniform: min, max, triangular: lower limit, upper limit, mode, trapezoidal: min, lower mode, upper mode, max. logit-logistic: location, scale, lower bound shift, upper bound shift, logit-normal: location, scale, lower bound shift, upper bound shift. beta: alpha, beta. prev.nexp List defining prevalence exposure among unexposed. risk List defining confounder-disease relative risk confounder-exposure odds ratio. first argument provides probability distribution function (constant, uniform, triangular, trapezoidal, log-logistic, log-normal) second parameters vector: constant: constant value, uniform: min, max, triangular: lower limit, upper limit, mode, trapezoidal: min, lower mode, upper mode, max. log-logistic: shape, rate. Must strictly positive, log-normal: meanlog, sdlog. mean standard deviation log scale. corr.p Correlation exposure-specific confounder prevalences. discard logical scalar. case negative adjusted count, draws discarded? set FALSE, negative counts set zero. alpha Significance level.

title: Probabilistic sensitivity analysis. — probsens
text: Probabilistic sensitivity analysis correct exposure misclassification outcome misclassification random error. Non-differential misclassification assumed two bias parameters seca.parms spca.parms provided. Adding 2 parameters seexp.parms spexp.parms (.e. providing 4 bias parameters) evaluates differential misclassification.

title: Probabilistic sensitivity analysis. — probsens
code: probsens(   case,   exposed,   type = c("exposure", "outcome"),   reps = 1000,   seca.parms = list(dist = c("constant", "uniform", "triangular", "trapezoidal",     "logit-logistic", "logit-normal", "beta"), parms = NULL),   seexp.parms = NULL,   spca.parms = list(dist = c("constant", "uniform", "triangular", "trapezoidal",     "logit-logistic", "logit-normal", "beta"), parms = NULL),   spexp.parms = NULL,   corr.se = NULL,   corr.sp = NULL,   discard = TRUE,   alpha = 0.05 )

title: Probabilistic sensitivity analysis. — probsens
text: case Outcome variable. variable, variable tabulated . exposed Exposure variable. type Choice correction exposure outcome misclassification. reps Number replications run. seca.parms List defining: sensitivity exposure classification among outcome (type = "exposure"), sensitivity outcome classification among exposure (type = "outcome"). first argument provides probability distribution function (constant, uniform, triangular, trapezoidal, logit-logistic, logit-normal, beta) second parameters vector. Logit-logistic logit-normal distributions can shifted providing lower upper bounds. Avoid providing values non-shifted distribution desired. constant: constant value, uniform: min, max, triangular: lower limit, upper limit, mode, trapezoidal: min, lower mode, upper mode, max, logit-logistic: location, scale, lower bound shift, upper bound shift, logit-normal: location, scale, lower bound shift, upper bound shift. beta: alpha, beta. seexp.parms List defining: sensitivity exposure classification among without outcome (type = "exposure"), sensitivity outcome classification among without exposure (type = "outcome"). spca.parms List seca.parms specificity. spexp.parms List seexp.parms specificity. corr.se Correlation case non-case sensitivities. corr.sp Correlation case non-case specificities. discard logical scalar. case negative adjusted count, draws discarded? set FALSE, negative counts set zero. alpha Significance level.

Supplementing # cancer registry data by case-control data. # Eur J Cancer Prev 2006;15:165-70. selection(matrix(c(136, 107, 297, 165), dimnames = list(c("UM+", "UM-"), c("Mobile+", "Mobile-")), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE), bias_parms = c(.94, .85, .64, .25)) #> --Observed data--  #>          Outcome: UM+  #>        Comparing: Mobile+ vs. Mobile-  #>  #>     Mobile+ Mobile- #> UM+     136     107 #> UM-     297     165 #>  #>                                        2.5%     97.5% #> Observed Relative Risk: 0.7984287 0.6518303 0.9779975 #>    Observed Odds Ratio: 0.7061267 0.5143958 0.9693215 #> --- #>                                                  #> Selection Bias Corrected Relative Risk: 1.483780 #>    Selection Bias Corrected Odds Ratio: 1.634608   selection(matrix(c(136, 107, 297, 165), dimnames = list(c("UM+", "UM-"), c("Mobile+", "Mobile-")), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE), bias_parms = 0.43) #> --Observed data--  #>          Outcome: UM+  #>        Comparing: Mobile+ vs. Mobile-  #>  #>     Mobile+ Mobile- #> UM+     136     107 #> UM-     297     165 #>  #>                                        2.5%     97.5% #> Observed Relative Risk: 0.7984287 0.6518303 0.9779975 #>    Observed Odds Ratio: 0.7061267 0.5143958 0.9693215 #> --- #>                                                  #> Selection Bias Corrected Relative Risk: 1.856811 #>    Selection Bias Corrected Odds Ratio: 1.642155

title: episensr 1.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-05-16 Fix CI plot.booted (@codiewood, #2) Replaced dot-dot notation after_stat(density) plot.probsens plot.booted misclassification_cov replaced misclassification.cov Standard output confounders.ext, confounders.limit, confounders.array Suggest tidyr instead tidyverse

title: episensr 1.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2021-08-20 Fix confidence interval values plotting output probsens. Fix bug created integer overflow rare cases 2--2 table cells large. Update documentation.

title: episensr 1.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2021-02-23 Provide default values variables mbias. Update M-bias plot using ggdag (dagitty). Add beta distribution probabilistic bias analyses. Plotting functions probabilistic bias analyses. Review criteria remove negative cell counts probabilistic bias analyses. Add citation DOI.

title: episensr 0.9.6

title: episensr 0.9.5
text: CRAN release: 2020-02-03 Fix selection-bias factor selection returning constant value.

title: episensr 0.9.4
text: CRAN release: 2019-09-02 Fix bias_parms selection use single selection-bias factor (skipping returning NAs).

title: episensr 0.9.3
text: CRAN release: 2018-12-03 Update description parms confounders, confounders.emm, confounders.poly New function confounders.array, sensitivity analysis unmeasured confounders based confounding imbalance among exposed unexposed (Schneeweiss, 2006) Deprecated bias parameters removed function multidimBias. Please use bias_parms instead. New function confounders.evalue, computing E-value assess bias due unmeasured confounder (VanderWeele Ding, 2017) New function multiple.bias allowing extract 2--2 table episensr object feed another function (multiple bias analysis)

title: episensr 0.9.2
text: CRAN release: 2017-11-13 Fix bug distributions computations /RR probsens.conf Update distributions probsens.irr.conf Add example using probsens.conf vignette

title: episensr 0.9.1

title: episensr 0.9.0
text: CRAN release: 2017-08-16 Add misclassification_cov misclassified covariate (confounder effect modifier). , (wrongly) added option misclassification previous version now removed. Add computation confidence interval odds ratio per Chu et al. exposure misclassification. Use bias_parms instead bias misclassification function.

title: episensr 0.8.0
text: CRAN release: 2017-01-04 Fix bug building 2--2 table. Various formatting improvements output confounders, confounders.emm, misclassification selection functions. Standardize use bias_parms. Add vignette. Selection bias factor now available output selection function. Add bootstrap option

title: episensr 0.7.2

title: episensr 0.7.1
text: CRAN release: 2015-10-05 Fix R version dependency (R >= 3.2.0)

title: episensr 0.7.0
text: CRAN release: 2015-10-01 Harmonization arguments across functions. New distributions added probsens series functions: constant, logit-logistic, logit-normal, log-logistic, log-normal. Probabilistic analysis person-time data added probsens.irr exposure misclassification, probsens.irr.conf unmeasured confounder. Sensitivity analysis correct selection bias caused M bias mbias function, including DAG plot print function. Fix CI formatting. NAMESPACE: add imports stats functions avoid new R CMD CHECK warnings
